transcription.text: So before we start, I'll talk a little bit about what we'll go over today.
So talk about a little bit about who we are at White Block and what our role is in ETH
Challenges to networking in ETH 2.
We'll go over a recap of the Interop Lock-In that we had in September and what our role
was there.
We're in a roadmap as well as a Q&A at the end.
So White Block is a team of engineers building tools to test blockchains, serving it systems,
protocols, what have you.
We have a core product called Genesis.
With Genesis, you can fully automate the creation and deployment of a blockchain.
You can configure network topologies, deterministically test how they'll react in real world and worst
case conditions.
We can do things like implement a network partition to force forking events and see how
your blockchain will react and reconcile the information.
The reason why we're talking about it is because we will use its functionality to test interoperability
in ETH 2.
Here we have everybody's favorite diagram, the networking old paradigm.
Sorry, it's a little messed up.
We just downloaded to PowerPoint and didn't have time to fix this.
You have a client creating server for information that it desires, server access the centralized
point of truth for that information.
Everybody knows this model.
That's why we're all here.
Cool.
So then you have blockchain networking, which is very, very difficult.
You have a bunch of nodes in the network that are tasked with challenge to communicate
over a large network and communicate with unknown peers at that.
So it gets pretty difficult.
In ETH 2 specifically, this means that you have nodes receiving messages of blocks and
attestations and propagating them to other nodes.
And they do this over an asynchronous communication pattern called gossip sub.
And we'll talk a little bit more about that later.
So nodes will receive a message and pass it on to their interested peers.
And the idea with gossip sub is that a message will efficiently propagate throughout the network
once the originating node broadcasts it out.
So nodes will request information they don't have from other nodes.
So if a node has adequate resources, it learns of a new block.
It will RPC request the block or the node that has that information to receive it.
Cool.
So there are a lot of challenges in distributing networking.
I don't know how aware you are of them, but we've listed very few of them.
But we're actively at Webblock looking at these challenges along with ETH 2 client teams,
ETH 2 research teams and other teams in the space looking at them.
So there's the issue of peer discovery.
How do you as a node find other nodes that you want to talk to in a large network?
The issue of distributed hash tables, so DHTs.
How do you store information about this peers in the network?
There's the issue of security.
How do you increase tolerance to certain kinds of attacks that are prevalent in distributed
networks like clips of tags, what have you?
The issue of block and attestation propagation, for which we will use gossip sub.
Again, we'll talk a little bit more about that in a second.
The issue of boot nodes in the network, which are points of centralization, perceived to
be points of weakness, issue of cryptographic verification, checking to make sure that signatures
are valid, hashes match block information, and then the issue of syncing.
So how do you efficiently sync and securely sync information against other nodes in the
network?
I'm sure that you guys have already had your ears talked off about libpDP at this conference.
It's been a super hot topic at DevCon.
If you want to go, we're only going to cover it briefly, but if you want to go more in
depth about it, Rol Kripalani from libpDP did a talk about gossip sub two days ago.
I'm sure the slides are already up on Twitter somewhere and the video will be uploaded,
but he did a really good deep dive into gossip sub.
We will cover just like very basically what gossip sub does so that we have a base to
start off at.
So gossip sub is an epidemic broadcast protocol.
It's an implementation of a pub sub communication pattern, and it's designed in such a way that
information will efficiently propagate across a network.
So nodes will listen for information that they want and pass it on to their peers that
want that information.
Pattern will continue until all nodes that are interested in that information have received
it in the network.
So gossip sub is an efficient protocol for propagating blocks and attestations in ETH
two, which is why it's used as the ETH two networking stack.
So back in April, we actually did a few preliminary tests on libpDP, and they were not so great.
But again, like Rol mentioned that libpDP is in alpha mode right now, so there are a
lot of parts of it that still need to be like massaged and improved to make sure that
it's going to be ready for phase year launch.
So we at white block will actually continue testing and auditing libpDP to ensure that
it will be ready for a successful phase year launch.
And I'm going to talk about that.
Yeah, now we're going to talk about testing.
Cool.
Thanks, Renee.
So why are we testing gossip sub?
So the point of this is to really assess the reward performance of gossip sub under very
adverse conditions, dropping peers, bad bandwidth, back at loss, huge latency between the nodes,
knowing that in the case of ETH two, we have six seconds per block.
So if you want to really gossip everything, you would want to have three seconds to gossip
the whole information between all the peers so they can decide and start voting, correct
correctly, on the new block.
One thing that we can really tweak during that testing is the different network topologies.
So if you went to Raul's talk, you said that you have a minimum of four peers, a maximum
of 12, is that really what we want to go for?
Should we have more peers?
Should we have a few better peers?
Should we start working a little bit on some of the working ones to do for episode where
we're going to have optimizations where we're going to prefer nodes which are closer to
us, which have lower latency, which are more responsive, we're going to look into that.
So to get to work, first thing we did is when we did our past April, we used the GoLipP2PD
man.
This time we're starting from scratch with a company called the agency Enterprise and
they're really great, they work really closely with protocol labs.
So Adam Henna has been building a LIPTP client which is based on the GoLipP2P core library.
And it's a very simple client that just is going to output a bunch of metadata information
about the message.
When it was sent, who sent it, who is it for, how many hops do you see for that message,
how long has it been around, how long was the hop between those different peers.
We also hired an academic on our team who is now doing literature review to look at the
different topologies, everything should be done there.
Namely right now, we'd like to try also to do some discovery associations so we can do
a cadmium approach to just let the network self-organize.
But it might actually not be the best way to organize the peers.
So we're testing all those different aspects.
So talking about network topologies, we're going to strain it, we're going to create
a sequence of peers, we're going to create a mesh of peers just like redundant hubs
between each other.
So we're going to really see that from node 1 to 100, we're going to have to traverse
all the nodes to get to that one.
So this is in progress.
You can check out those two repos.
The first one here is our project management repo.
This is all the issues, kind of reflect the work from the team.
You can take a look.
Contribution is a very welcome.
Your feedback in the issues you see.
The work itself, the benchmark tool is actually under agency enterprise.
You can take a look at it.
You can run it right now.
The idea is that we're going to dockerize at work and then deploy it on Genesis.
We're going to run, you know, 30, 100 of those in parallel.
And we had some unexpected good news, I don't know if I'm here, but we got access to an

So we're starting testing X3D this week.
We got a guy on this.
We're going to publish all the raw data sets for every test suite on Google Cloud Storage.
You can download those.
They're 1.5 gigabytes each.
So it's quite a bit of data.
And then we'll also share the Python parsing script that we use to read all the logs, to

And we'll make that open source as well.
Probably, and there's the PM repo.
So the idea is that we want to be completely transparent, make sure that our work is being

That if you have an idea or a suggestion for a different type of testing, you can come

We can have a conversation about this and we can come together and collaborate on all

So to switch gears, this is coming a little bit also from our work with Ethereum 2.
So just going to do a little recap on the interrupt workshop that we did in September.
Here you can see these are stand up in the morning.
Danny Ryan's telling us how things are going.
We're going by team.
Here you have different teams working together, working on the same laptops.
So the purpose of interrupt for us was to establish communications between the teams
to make sure that they had a good process to work together.
Being into interrupt, we just wanted people to just take one laptop, two clients, make
them work and see if they're able to even just gossip a block, say hello, have some
information.
We had some great tooling from Porto Lambda from the Ethereum Foundation.
So he gave us a way to regenerate Genesis State, like 30 seconds or one minute in future, that
everybody could ingest as well as the list of validators that would be associated with
each client and then it would give us the ability to very quickly set up this type of
scenarios.
Initially, what the clients did was only one client in the testnet would have validators,
everybody else would be passive and ingesting all the data.
And as we got closer to the end of the week, everybody was able to have validators at the
same time, so everybody was producing blocks.
We had to get everybody going.
A good caveat of this is that it's a little jurrigged because we had to kind of go with
the flow of those different clients.
Some clients did not support sync, for example.
So if they started after the Genesis time, they would not have a good time working with
the others.
So you also, to give you an idea, it was very manual.
They would have a TMAX window at first, start first client, look at the inode of that client,
paste that into the start script of the second client, start the second client, start a search
client, etc., etc.
Very manual.
But for first try, that was a good try.
So we had a few panics, we had a few interesting crashes.
We saw all the things that could go wrong.
And well, eventually, they managed to get some clients on laptop, which is a pretty good
result.
Much better than we anticipated going in.
So eventually, what we want to do now is to actually productize this.
So recap of the success, we had seven clients talking to each other on a local machine.
A little harder for us, we were using Docker.
And now we want to productize what they've done into whether it's completely automated.
So for us, it was a little harder because each client is ever so slightly different.
I'm going to go into that.
The way we run things with Genesis is that we pretty much take whatever Docker image a blockchain
client has, and we just automate its creation and its lifecycle as part of a platform.
So it's very easy for us once everything is in place to go very quickly to a test net
and to just generate many of them.
So things that kind of took a bit of time to figure out.
We saw that even so everybody's using lipid2p, when you have an address for a client for
a node in lipid2p, you can do a couple of different things.
You can have the public key of your client being published to all your peers.
We can choose not to do that.
And when they connect to each other, that's when the public key gets exchanged.
So in that case, for example, some clients would just barf because they didn't want to
have the public key of the other node in there.
So we had to start tweaking for that, like lighthast didn't like that.
So we have to change the start script just for them, et cetera.
We saw also that they have a different ways of storing the identity key, the key that actually
represents the identity of the node.
Lip2p by default is going to use a port above format, which adds two bytes to the beginning
of the string that we store.
Some clients like that as an exactissimal string being passed, some like that as a basic
default string to be passed, and some like that in your file.
So we had to account for all those different variances of the way they would consume the
information.
All this, of course, works very well when you're doing static peering.
At this point, I think we have two clients that do disk v5 that might be wrong.
So that's something that we need to look at next.
So we're going to talk a little bit about that quickly.
For us, it was kind of a great learning experiment.
We're going to generalize our framework to make it much easier to accommodate those clients
without changes as much as possible.
So discovering.
I love discovering v5.
I need to make stickers for this.
It's a big change from if one.
You know, if one you used to have just the URL being broadcasted to all your peers, and
you would have those kinemia buckets where it would be organized.
In discovery v5, you now have the notion of if you have node records, which are still
signed or still making sense.
It's a little bit of security.
You can do a handshake.
You can kind of make sure you're not being spammed as much.
But what comes with E&Rs is now the ability for you to have in those key value pairs,
it can arbitrarily store in them a notion of topics.
So you can actually, when you come and broadcast yourself to others, tell that you're an if
to node or you're an if to one node or you'll poke a node.
So this allows other blockchains to also participate in a global DHT, this new KWDHT,
which is also simpler than it used to be.
So it's going to allow better security.
So back six months ago, Flixlange came to New York, and one thing that he mentioned is
that this KWDHT will only work if you have over a thousand nodes running it.
Otherwise, the security is going to be compromised by Eclipse attacks very quickly.
So this is a huge effort, going to allow if one is need to also share some of the work
and to share some of the infrastructure.
So really excited about this as a network geek.
So next steps for us.
So we're recipient of the NIF Grant.
We thank the EFRAM Foundation for helping us in sponsoring this effort.
